skill.name: nextjs-app-router-patterns
skill.description: Master Next.js 14+ App Router with Server Components, streaming, parallel routes, and advanced data fetching. Use when building Next.js applications, implementing SSR/SSG, or optimizing React Server Components.
skill.summary: Master Next.js 14+ App Router with Server Components, streaming, parallel routes, and advanced data ...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown explanations and TypeScript code examples. No executable scripts, network calls, filesystem access, or external commands are implemented. All code is illustrative documentation.

content.value_statement: App Router features can be hard to structure and choose. This skill provides clear patterns and examples for Next.js 14+ routing, data fetching, and Server Components.
actual_capabilities: Explain Server Components versus Client Components
List App Router file conventions for layouts and routes
Provide Server Actions patterns for mutations and redirects
Describe parallel and intercepting routes with examples
Outline caching, revalidation, and metadata patterns
Show route handler patterns for API routes
limitations: Does not run code or access project files
Examples use placeholder APIs and databases
Focuses on App Router, not Pages Router
Does not generate full projects or migration scripts

use_cases.title: Start an App Router build
use_cases.description: Get a clear structure for layouts, loading states, and data fetching in a new Next.js 14+ app.

use_cases.title: Plan routing architecture
use_cases.description: Design parallel and intercepting routes for dashboards and complex flows with consistent loading UI.

use_cases.title: Optimize data fetching
use_cases.description: Choose caching and revalidation strategies for product listings and detail pages.

prompt_templates.title: App Router basics
prompt_templates.scenario: You are new to App Router
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain the core App Router file conventions and when to use Server Components versus Client Components.

prompt_templates.title: Add Server Actions
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a Server Actions pattern for adding an item to a cart with revalidation and redirect.

prompt_templates.title: Parallel routes plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Suggest a parallel routes structure with loading states for analytics and team panels.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced caching
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend caching and revalidation choices for product listings and detail pages with tag invalidation.

output_examples.input: Show a simple plan for a product page with streaming and caching.
output: Use a server component for the product header so it renders first
Wrap reviews and recommendations in Suspense with loading UI
Apply tag based revalidation on product fetches for controlled cache refresh

best_practices: Start with Server Components and add client only when needed
Colocate data fetching with the component that uses it
Use Suspense boundaries to enable streaming and clear loading states
anti_patterns: Fetching critical data in Client Components without a server fallback
Over nesting layouts that inflate render trees
Skipping loading states for slow data sources

faq.question: Is this compatible with Next.js 14 and 15
faq.answer: Yes. It targets App Router patterns that remain compatible with Next.js 14 and 15.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill
faq.answer: It provides guidance and examples, but it does not run code or build projects.

faq.question: Can I use this with an existing App Router app
faq.answer: Yes. You can apply the patterns incrementally to your current structure.

faq.question: Does it access my data or files
faq.answer: No. It only provides guidance and does not access local data.

faq.question: What if a pattern conflicts with my setup
faq.answer: Share your constraints and request a tailored variation of the pattern.

faq.question: How does it compare to official docs
faq.answer: It summarizes and organizes patterns with examples. The official docs remain the primary reference.
